Event: Target received spear-phishing email with signed .rdp attachment
Justification: Microsoft & CERT-UA observed targeted emails that included signed .rdp attachments impersonating vendors/Microsoft.

Event: Victim opened .rdp file -> mstsc invoked (RDP connect)
Justification: Opening .rdp launches mstsc.exe with .rdp args; documented in CERT-UA screenshots and Microsoft advisory.

Event: RDP session established to attacker-controlled server
Justification: RDP connection to external host provides interactive access to files/peripherals and may lead to further access.

Event: Attacker collects credentials or captures credential input during RDP session
ATT&CK_Technique_Name: Credentials from Password Stores: Credential Manager
Justification: Attacker-controlled RDP server may present login prompts or proxy credentials; credential capture is a likely objective.
Expected_Logs_Artifacts: EDR traces of LSASS access or credential-store access

ATT&CK_Tactic: actor may use app-layer C2 channels
Expected_Logs_Artifacts: Follow-on tools or callbacks would likely use HTTP/DNS to blend with normal traffic and stage actions.

Event: Actor may create persistence mechanisms on compromised hosts
Justification: Possible persistence via scheduled tasks, services, Run keys or similar after RDP-based access.

Event: Use of masquerading and signed files to reduce suspicion
ATT&CK_Technique_Name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Justification: Use of signed .rdp attachments and legitimate-looking filenames to evade detection and social-engineer targets.
